author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: In Dublin’s Pubs, Raising a Farewell Pint to Shane MacGowan
description: The Pogues singer, who died Thursday, took traditional Irish music in a new direction. Most people in Ireland loved him for it.
content: Christmas came early this year in Dublin, but too late for a beloved adopted son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: Kiss Loves to Say Goodbye. Is Its Rock ’n’ Roll Really Over?
description: Farewell tours are one of pop music’s signature moves. But there’s reason to believe Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley are throwing in the towel for real this time.
content: When Kiss plays Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, it will bring down the curtain on the band’s End of the Road farewell tour, which began in January 2019. “We’re gonna go out on top,” the bassist Gene Simmons said last year during an interview with the Los Angeles radio station KLOS-FM. There will be no more Kiss tours, he’s vowed, not ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Jeff Bezos’ Giant Yacht Is Apparently Too Big to Anchor Near Others in Florida
description: The superyacht, called Koru, arrived in Port Everglades in Florida on Nov. 22, and has been docked near a more-than 610-foot-long oil tanker named Magnolia State.
content: First, Jeff Bezos’ new megayacht was too big to pass under a bridge in the Netherlands. Now, the massive vessel’s size — it’s more than 400 feet long — has played a role in preventing it from keeping company with other private yachts in Port Everglades, Fla., where it is anchored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Valery Gergiev, a Putin Ally, Chosen to Lead Bolshoi Theater
description: The Russian maestro, who heads the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, will also control the Bolshoi in Moscow, replacing Vladimir Urin, who spoke out against the Ukraine war.
content: Valery Gergiev, the star Russian maestro and prominent supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin, was tapped on Friday to lead the storied Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, the Russian government announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Grace Ashford
title: George Santos Is Kicked Out of Congress in a Historic Vote
description: Nearly half of the G.O.P. House delegation voted to expel Mr. Santos, a remarkable rebuke of a colleague who had survived two prior expulsion bids.
content: George Santos, the New York Republican congressman whose tapestry of lies and schemes made him a figure of national ridicule and the subject of a 23-count federal indictment, was expelled from the House on Friday after a decisive bipartisan vote by his peers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Victoria Kim, Michael Crowley and Ben Hubbard
title: Talks were continuing in hopes of reviving the truce.
description: A weeklong cease-fire in the Gaza Strip collapsed on Friday morning, with both Israel and Hamas blaming the other for the breakdown of the fragile truce that had allowed for the exchange of scores of hostages and prisoners, and had briefly raised hopes for a more lasting halt to the fighting.
content: A weeklong cease-fire in the Gaza Strip collapsed on Friday morning, with both Israel and Hamas blaming the other for the breakdown of the fragile truce that had allowed for the exchange of scores of hostages and prisoners, and had briefly raised hopes for a more lasting halt to the fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: John Woo Has Seen a Lot in Hollywood. He’s Finally Back for More.
description: The director reflects on why he left in the first place, how he was able to work with Tom Cruise and what’s next for action films.
content: When John Woo was a child, living in the dangerous slums of Hong Kong, he had two sanctuaries: the church and the movie theater. Both provided respite from a world of poverty and intense violence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pickup or Lunar Lander? Tesla’s Cybertruck Arrives.
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 1, 2023.
content: “It looks like something lowered from the lunar module to collect rocks on the moon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Surging U.S. Oil Production Brings Down Prices and Raises Climate Fears
description: American oil production is hitting record levels, delivering economic and foreign policy benefits but putting environmental goals further out of reach.
content: American oil fields are gushing again, helping to drive down fuel prices but also threatening to undercut efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Has Brought You Joy in 2023
description: Dropping your children off at college for the first time, international travel and more.
content: Happy Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: U.S. Navy Works to Salvage Plane From Fragile Hawaiian Bay
description: The maritime patrol aircraft overshot a runway at a U.S. Marine Corps base and landed in the water. The Navy plans to haul it out on Saturday.
content: In the crystal-clear waters of Kaneohe Bay, a U.S. Navy patrol aircraft that weighs over 130,000 pounds is stuck atop a fragile reef ecosystem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How Do the Pros Create Holiday Magic? (Yes, You Can Try This at Home.)
description: Whether you’re a minimalist, a maximalist or agnostic about holiday decorating, these designers have some suggestions for you.
content: It’s that time of year again. The Thanksgiving leftovers are gone, and the December holidays beckon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Corina Knoll
title: Los Angeles Officials Search for Killer Said to Be ‘Preying on the Unhoused’
description: The police are desperately looking for a gunman they believe is responsible for shooting three men dead on the streets of Los Angeles this week.
content: The Los Angeles police are searching for a man they believe shot three homeless people dead this week, prompting officials on Friday to urge anyone sleeping on the streets to find shelter indoors or avoid sleeping alone until the killer is found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao, Karen Zraick, Anushka Patil and Gaya Gupta
title: Freed Palestinians Were Mostly Young and Not Convicted of Crimes
description: Israel has released a total of 240 Palestinian prisoners and detainees during a weeklong pause in hostilities.
content: Israel released a total of 240 Palestinian prisoners and detainees in exchange for 105 hostages freed by Hamas during a weeklong pause in hostilities, an arrangement that diplomats had tried to extend before it collapsed into fighting on Friday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: King Charles Urges ‘Transformational Action’ at COP28 Climate Summit
description: “The hope of the world rests on the decisions you must take,” the British monarch told world leaders at the U.N. climate summit in Dubai.
content: King Charles III challenged a gathering of world leaders to take “genuine transformational action” to slow the spiral of greenhouse gas emissions, declaring that “the hope of the world rests on the decisions you must take.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Court Extends Detention of U.S. Journalist
description: Alsu Kurmasheva, an editor who also holds Russian citizenship, was arrested in October on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent.
content: A Russian court on Friday extended the detention of an editor working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a broadcaster funded by the American government, who was arrested in October on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Elon Musk Is Making a Giant Mistake … Unless?
description: It’s unlikely, but he might actually know what he’s doing.
content: Elon Musk is so smart that you have to wonder if trashing X, formerly Twitter, is somehow in his best interest. This couldn’t possibly be one giant mistake, could it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Sandra Day O’Connor, First Woman on the Supreme Court, Is Dead at 93
description: During a crucial period in American law — when abortion, affirmative action, sex discrimination and voting rights were on the docket — she was the most powerful woman in the country.
content: Sandra Day O’Connor, the first woman on the United States Supreme Court, a rancher’s daughter who wielded great power over American law from her seat at the center of the court’s ideological spectrum, died on Friday in Phoenix. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis Super PAC Suffers Another Big Staff Loss, This Time Its Chairman
description: The departure of Adam Laxalt, a longtime friend of the Florida governor, is the latest shake-up inside Never Back Down as it faces questions over the group’s strategy and spending.
content: The main super PAC supporting Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign has been rocked by another significant departure, as Adam Laxalt, a friend and former roommate of the Florida governor, has stepped down as chairman of the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Mother With ‘Doomsday’ Beliefs, Lori Vallow Daybell, Is Extradited to Arizona
description: Ms. Vallow Daybell was convicted in Idaho in May in the murders of two of her children and of conspiring to murder her husband’s previous wife. She faces charges in other cases.
content: Lori Vallow Daybell, who is serving consecutive life sentences in Idaho for murdering two of her children after being inspired by what prosecutors called her “doomsday” beliefs, has been extradited to Arizona to face charges of conspiracy to commit murder in two other cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
title: Best Movies of 2023
description: It was a terrific year for film, whether art house or mainstream, even if the main subject the movies wrestled with was deeply pessimistic.
content: I had a terrific movie year — you? I saw hundreds of new films with a variety of plots and styles made on every imaginable scale and budget. Some were from newcomers like A.V. Rockwell and others from the ever-new Martin Scorsese. Some you’ve heard of or will, while others scarcely made a ripple. Some were released by independents like A24 and the tiny KimStim; others came from tech companies and still others from what are now often called legacy studios, a vaguely eulogistic term that suggests influence but also obsolescence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Israel Resumed its Gaza Offensive
description: Also, George Santos was expelled from Congress.
content: A weeklong cease-fire in the Gaza Strip collapsed this morning, with both Israel and Hamas blaming the other for the breakdown of the fragile truce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: The Eagles Release a Christmas Album. Not Those Eagles.
description: The 2018 Super Bowl champions sing — yes, sing — alongside legends such as Patti LaBelle for charity.
content: Jordan Mailata, the 6-foot-8, 365-pound left tackle for the Philadelphia Eagles, was nervous for his next matchup. It was August, and he was heading into the recording studio to duet with the Godmother of Soul, Patti LaBelle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Larissa Anderson and Daniel Ramirez
title: A Film by Beyoncé
description: Our culture critics J Wortham and Salamishah Tillet discuss the icon’s concert film from her Renaissance tour.
content: “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé” is out today. It’s a nearly three-hour documentary of the pop icon’s record-breaking summer tour and provides audiences with both a front-row seat and behind-the-scenes look at the show. J Wortham and Salamishah Tillet discuss what the film means for the artist at the height of her powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m White. Should I Repatriate My African Art?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to return artwork to its original source.
content: I was privileged to have been raised in a family who prized the arts, including works from cultures that were not our own. (We are of European ancestry.) Among the art in my childhood home was a significant collection of masks, statues, figurines and other objects from mostly West African cultures. My father, who acquired these pieces in the 1970s and ’80s through art dealers, has always taken pride in the idea that they were not “tourist art.” Most of the items date to the 19th and early 20th centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: A New York Philharmonic Staple Outshines a Flashy Premiere
description: Rachmaninoff’s Symphonic Dances was the highlight of a program that also included the New York debut of Bryce Dessner’s evocative Concerto for Two Pianos.
content: On Thursday, the New York Philharmonic gave the New York premiere of a double piano concerto by a pop artist with classical and indie rock credentials. With the composer in attendance, the piece, lovingly crafted to show off the evening’s soloists, Katia and Marielle Labèque, had a strong claim as the evening’s centerpiece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: An Abundance of Old-Fashioned Yarns to Close Out the Year
description: A secret, a disappearance, a frozen body and a mysterious stranger — these historical novels have something for everyone.
content: This has been a banner year for historical fiction and it’s not over yet. Here, for your holiday consideration, are six recently published historical novels that would make fine gifts — or fine rewards when you reach the end of that long shopping list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Trump Lawyer Tells Judge a Georgia Trial Would Be ‘Election Interference’
description: Arguments in court on Friday offered clues to Donald J. Trump’s legal strategy in fighting state charges of conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election.
content: A lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump argued in an Atlanta courtroom on Friday that putting his client on trial in the final stages of the 2024 presidential contest would be “the most effective election interference in the history of the United States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Hulu and More in December
description: Holiday fare arrives, with “Candy Cane Lane,” and “Dr. Who” and “Shape Island” specials. “Percy Jackson” and “Culprits” also land this month.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of December’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jung Kook, BTS and English Language K-Pop
description: A conversation about K-pop’s long march to American awareness, and the potential risks of that embrace.
content: A few weeks ago, Jung Kook — a member of the world-beating K-pop group BTS — released his solo debut album, “Golden,” a sleek affair notable for high-profile collaborators on its tracks and behind the scenes, as well as for the fact that it’s sung fully in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Simple Bread Pudding Makes a Plush Dessert
description: Serve it after a big pot of clam chowder or a burly kale salad.
content: Good morning. There’s turkey stock in the freezer, but the rest of the Thanksgiving leftovers are gone: made into stews, sandwiches, quesadillas, beds for evening eggs. It was a lovely week of feasting. Now we’re on to Cookie Week, holiday ham and the sprint to the end of the year. Buckle up!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: There Is No Way to Live a Life Without Regret
description: The panic over transgender children is driven by the fear that they’ll regret transitioning. But freedom to make mistakes is core to being human.
content: When I was in sixth grade, I made a decision that changed the course of my life. I decided not to try out for the middle school swim team. I know that might not sound like a big deal, but it was. As a grade schooler I was a standout swimmer — strong shoulders and back, and well-muscled legs that powered me through the water with ease and speed. I was disciplined, obsessive. My form was excellent. My coach saw potential.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Ultimate Brenda Lee Primer
description: Listen to 11 songs that show she’s more than her classic, “Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree.”
content: Sitting at No. 8 on this week’s Billboard Hot 100 — right between a sleek hit from the 20-year-old pop star Tate McRae and the latest offering from Taylor Swift’s vault — is a 65-year-old song, sung by an artist who is about to turn 79. Which, if you do the math (I’ll wait), means that artist recorded it when she was just 13.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Court Rejects Jussie Smollett’s Appeal of Hoax Case Conviction
description: An appellate court in Illinois upheld the actor’s conviction on charges of filing a false police report claiming he was the subject of a racist and homophobic attack in 2019.
content: An appellate court in Illinois on Friday rejected Jussie Smollett’s challenge of his conviction on charges of filing a false police report about a racist and homophobic attack in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Rent or Buy?
description: We explain the state of the housing market.
content: Should you rent or buy your next home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Victor Mather
title: Sandra Day O’Connor Is Celebrated as a ‘Trailblazer’
description: Public figures from across the political spectrum heralded the former Supreme Court justice for breaking barriers for women and striving for consensus on the nation’s highest court.
content: One adjective was invoked more than any other to describe Sandra Day O’Connor immediately after her death at 93 on Friday: “trailblazing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Toobin
title: Sandra Day O’Connor Never Stopped Being a Politician
description: Justice O’Connor loved being a politician and, in a way, never stopped being one.
content: Sandra Day O’Connor, who died on Friday, is forever linked to the word “first” — the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court. But especially when thinking about today’s court, the word that may describe her best is “last” — the last former politician to be a justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Inmate Stabbed Derek Chauvin 22 Times, U.S. Says
description: John Turscak, 52, has been charged with attempting to murder Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who is serving more than two decades in prison for the murder of George Floyd.
content: An inmate stabbed Derek Chauvin 22 times last week at a federal prison in Tucson, Ariz., the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Arizona said on Friday in announcing attempted murder charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emilia Petrarca
title: A Designer Inspired by Black Elegance, Soca Music and Blue Devils
description: Maximilian Davis, Ferragamo’s creative director, shares a glimpse into his creative world.
content: Less than a week after presenting his third collection as Ferragamo’s creative director in Milan this past September, Maximilian Davis was at ease. The clothes — a luxurious combination of asymmetrical dresses and Italian tailoring — had been well received. As he spoke, quietly but with confidence, he gestured gently with his hands, like a conductor keeping an unhurried tempo. Born in Manchester, England, to Trinidadian and Jamaican parents, Davis, 28, the youngest of three children, spent his summers in Trinidad until the age of 13. A passion for clothing ran in the family: His maternal grandmother taught him to sew when he was 6, his mother was a working model and his father studied fashion design.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Kendrick Lamar Buys a Penthouse on the Brooklyn Waterfront
description: The award-winning rapper paid $8.6 million for a duplex at Pierhouse at Brooklyn Bridge Park, adding to his bicoastal portfolio of real estate.
content: The rapper Kendrick Lamar is the latest celebrity to descend on Brooklyn, with his purchase of a sprawling duplex penthouse near the waterfront in Brooklyn Heights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: U.S. Appeals Court Orders Texas to Remove Buoy Barrier in Rio Grande
description: Gov. Greg Abbott’s office has said the floating buoys are needed to restrict migrants entering from Mexico. The federal government said they were illegal.
content: A federal appeals court on Friday ordered the state of Texas to remove a barrier of floating buoys in the Rio Grande installed at the direction of Gov. Greg Abbott to block migrants trying to cross from Mexico, delivering a blow to the state’s efforts to curtail unauthorized immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Madonna Lived to Tell
description: Inspired by an Instagram account dedicated to AIDS, the singer mounts a moving and trenchant piece of political theater for her “Celebration” tour.
content: Shining out from the Instagram slag heap, amid the endless A.I. selfies and reaction reels, is an account so quiet in presence and noble in intention that it is sometimes hard to believe it exists. The account, The AIDS Memorial, is an evolving testament, told in photographs, videos and user stories, to lives lost to a devastating and, it can occasionally seem, forgotten epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
title: Israel Knew Hamas’s Attack Plan More Than a Year Ago
description: A blueprint reviewed by The Times laid out the attack in detail. Israeli officials dismissed it as aspirational and ignored specific warnings.
content: Israeli officials obtained Hamas’s battle plan for the Oct. 7 terrorist attack more than a year before it happened, documents, emails and interviews show. But Israeli military and intelligence officials dismissed the plan as aspirational, considering it too difficult for Hamas to carry out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: Game, Set and a Match for a Former Tennis Pro
description: Shortly after meeting online, Julia Elbaba traveled from New York to Virginia to see Matthew Nevulis. When the Covid lockdown began, seven days extended into three months of living together.
content: When Julia Margaux Elbaba and Dr. Matthew George Nevulis matched on Bumble in early 2019, neither was in a position to make a long-distance relationship work. Dr. Nevulis lived in Charlottesville, Va., where he was completing his medical residency at the University of Virginia. Ms. Elbaba was traveling the world as a professional tennis player, with a home base in Oyster Bay, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: With Santos Ouster, a Chaotic Congress Makes History Again
description: A Republican-led House known for dysfunction managed to purge a serial fabulist from its ranks, but the expulsion threatened to make it even harder for the G.O.P. to govern.
content: Moments after House members cast a historic vote to expel Representative George Santos of New York, Speaker Mike Johnson banged the gavel with a grim look on his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Scientists in Discredited Alcohol Study Will Not Advise U.S. on Drinking Guidelines
description: Two researchers with ties to beer and liquor companies had been named to a panel that will review the health evidence on alcohol consumption. But after a New York Times story was published, the panel’s organizers decided to drop them.
content: Five years ago, the National Institutes of Health abruptly pulled the plug on an ambitious study about the health effects of moderate drinking. The reason: The trial’s principal scientist and officials from the federal agency’s own alcohol division had solicited $60 million for the research from alcohol manufacturers, a conflict of interest and a violation of federal policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: Meet Progressive’s Flo. Also: Longevity drugs for dogs and the best books of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: George Santos Is Gone. Two Dozen Candidates Want His Seat.
description: The New York Republican’s expulsion sets the stage for a high-stakes special election early next year to fill his Long Island swing seat.
content: The expulsion of George Santos from Congress on Friday swept away one major political headache for Republicans, but it immediately set the stage for another: The party will have to defend his vulnerable seat in a special election early next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Rishi Sunak promises to honor Britain’s climate commitments in a ‘more pragmatic way.’
description: The prime minister rejected claims that he had lowered his country’s climate ambitions.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain rejected claims on Friday that he had lowered his country’s net-zero ambitions and pledged to meet targets in a more pragmatic way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Julia Jacobs
title: After Sexual Assault Suits, Are Sean Combs’s Empire and Brand at Risk?
description: The music mogul has been celebrated as a transformative force in hip-hop, but fallout from new accusations of abuse has impacted some business relationships and his legacy.
content: A few months ago, Sean Combs was doing a victory lap for his three-decade career as a producer, music executive and all-around hip-hop showman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Alleged Plot to Kill Sikh Separatist Highlights Thorn in India’s Side
description: The charges are rooted in a decades-old dispute over the demand by some Sikhs for a sovereign state known as Khalistan carved out of northern India.
content: The federal indictment this week of an Indian citizen in an alleged murder-for-hire scheme targeting a Sikh separatist in New York threatens to damage ties between the United States and India just as the Biden administration has been courting Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: At ‘Dancing With Glass,’ the Spotlight Rests on the Composer
description: The five dance selections that are part of the Dance Reflections festival take varied approaches to piano exercises written by Philip Glass.
content: “Dancing With Glass: The Piano Etudes” is titled a little misleadingly. The five dance selections on the program, now at the Joyce Theater as part of the Dance Reflections festival, are all set to piano études by Philip Glass. But before and after each, the pianist Maki Namekawa plays another of the Glass keyboard exercises. Really, the show is Glass with dancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: A Shot at Building a Stand-Up Career in 15 Minutes or Less
description: The path forward for comedians is especially confusing now. Netflix’s “Verified” showcases are giving them a national stage, even if they have to share it.
content: How in the world do you make it in stand-up comedy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Quittner
title: Flamboyant as Ever, ’70s-Style Desserts Are Making a Comeback
description: With nostalgia comes Bundts, Black Forests and elaborate gelatinous confections. Would you like a blowtorch with that?
content: WHEN THE NEW York chef and restaurateur Angie Mar was developing the dessert menu for her new Manhattan restaurant, Le B — where she serves an opulent take on continental cuisine — she wasn’t interested in subtlety. “I always love excess,” says Mar, 41. “And when I think about a ’70s dinner party, I think about excess.” She decided to revive two of the decade’s most popular desserts: the soufflé and the showstopping Black Forest cake. Mar’s riff on the latter — traditionally a chocolate cake layered with kirsch-soaked cherries and whipped cream — pairs oozing, gastrique-infused Bings with fudgy chocolate, a fluffy quenelle of rum-spiked Chantilly cream and a smattering of lacy almond tuiles. Meticulously composed and a little bit weird, the dish wouldn’t look out of place in Salvador Dalí’s 1973 cookbook, “Les Dîners de Gala,” a chronicle of the Surrealist feasts he hosted with Gala Dalí, his wife and muse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: What Is Happening in Vermont?
description: For many in Vermont, the horror of a shooting of Palestinians was compounded by the violation of the state’s self-image as a uniquely welcoming place.
content: The first sign that something was amiss came in the form of three police cruisers idling, unbidden, in the lot behind the Islamic Society of Vermont, the state’s largest mosque, last Saturday night in South Burlington. Usually there would be only one cop, paid for by the mosque during gatherings like the community potluck being held that evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: 3-Year-Old Boy Killed in Hit and Run in Queens
description: Quintus Chen, of Flushing, was struck by a car that was pulling away from the curb. A 20-year-old man was charged with leaving the scene of a deadly accident.
content: A 3-year-old boy was killed in a hit and run in Queens on Wednesday night, the fifth child to be killed by a vehicle this year in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Noah Kahan, Low-Key Superstar, Contemplates ‘Stick Season’
description: In the woods of central Vermont, where he wrote his hit album, the singer-songwriter reflects on his newfound fame and wonders why he smashed that guitar.
content: Four German shepherds — Penny, Oma, Meadow and Poncho — came bounding out of a house that sits on a hilltop in central Vermont. They sniffed out the approaching stranger before deciding to grant passage. Noah Kahan, a 26-year-old singer-songwriter who became an unlikely sensation this year, emerged from the house and corralled the pack with a series of gentle commands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Donald Trump Still Wants to Kill Obamacare. Why?
description: Is this really about policy, or is it personal?
content: Donald Trump hasn’t talked much about policy in this election cycle, except for vague assertions that he’ll somehow bring back low unemployment and low inflation — which, by the way, has already happened. (Unemployment has been at or below 4 percent for almost two years. Thursday’s report on consumer spending showed the Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of underlying inflation getting close to its 2 percent target.) Most of his energy seems to be devoted to the prospect of wreaking revenge on his political opponents, whom he promises to “root out” like “vermin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Turse
title: Ask Brutalized Cambodians What They Think of Kissinger
description: His policies toward civilians in the Vietnam War set a template that would be followed by the U.S. for decades.
content: Forty years after the American military attacked them, the people of Tropeang Phlong village in Cambodia were still traumatized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Congestion Pricing Is Coming. Its Opponents Are Still Furious.
description: The nation’s first congestion pricing program is taking final shape in New York. Supporters say it will benefit the city, but foes fear its impact on drivers.
content: Commuters worry their drives into Lower Manhattan will cost more. Residents fear their neighborhoods will be swarmed by new traffic. Taxi drivers are terrified of losing more customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Curse’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: A Man Possessed
description: Whitney and Asher receive good news as the show continues to dip further into the surreal.
content: I rewound the final beat of this week’s episode of “The Curse” immediately after first watching it, and have found myself revisiting it many times since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel’s Next Aim Is Southern Gaza. U.S. Urges Restraint.

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Farewell to George Santos, the Perfect MAGA Republican
description: No one embodies Trump’s fame-obsessed sociopathic emptiness like George Santos.
content: Should the blessed day ever arrive when Donald Trump is sent to federal prison, only one of his acolytes has earned the right to share his cell: George Santos, who on Friday became the sixth person in history to be expelled from the House of Representatives, more than seven months after he was first charged with crimes including fraud and money laundering. (He’s pleaded not guilty.) A clout-chasing con man obsessed with celebrity, driven into politics not by ideology but by vanity and the promise of proximity to rich marks, Santos is a pure product of Trump’s Republican Party. “At nearly every opportunity, he placed his desire for private gain above his duty to uphold the Constitution, federal law and ethical principles,” said a House Ethics Committee report about Santos released last month. He’s a true child of the MAGA movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: When Women Artists Choose Mothering Over Making Work
description: Why does the act of stepping away from a creative vocation still have the power to shock?
content: HERE IS THE myth of how the punk singer and poet Patti Smith vanished for 16 years: In 1979, at the age of 32, she said goodbye to her band, the public and New York for a life with the man who would soon be her husband, the guitarist Fred “Sonic” Smith, in his hometown of Detroit. Soon after, they moved to the suburbs — the very place punks were supposed to be trying to escape, the turf of those enemies, Mom and Dad — and bought a three-bedroom Tudor house in St. Clair Shores, where they raised two children; where they became Mom and Dad. This idyll didn’t last. Fred Smith died young, of heart failure, in 1994 and, after a period of mourning, Patti Smith returned to New York and the music scene. Of her time away from her career, she told The Times in 1995, “There’s no job harder than being a wife and a mother.”

Then, why people are still buying cryptocurrency even after Binance, the world’s largest crypto exchange, and its founder pleaded guilty to money laundering violations. That lighthearted spirit is on display at the label’s new flagship, a combination boutique, office, atelier and two-suite minihotel now open for booking. One enters the four-story spot, located in a neo-Classical Ninth Arrondissement building, through a tent made from the same blue striped Pierre Frey fabric that adorns the walls of Napoleon’s Château de Malmaison. Inside, a vintage Denon DP-3000 turntable and Continental Edison speakers blast 1970s funk.

title: Hamas and the Memory of the Holocaust

In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.
